pros: If you want to develop a thick skin, where a lot of external negativity can't get to you or if you want to appear a good candidate to other e-commerce ventures or startups, having foodpanda on your CV can give you a headstart.
cons: It has an atrocious work culture where hard work is very rarely recognised. The mindset is to consistently overwork employees and when they burn out, to throw them under the bus. There is no job security and initially that seems like an exciting challenge to take on, to see if you can survive but there's no way you can stick to a place for a year just to prove a point to yourself. There's zero investment towards training of employees. The management's approach is usually to hurl blame at their subordinates and to give them insane targets that don't even completely fall under employees' domain. The way the upper management communicates to you is very unprofessional. It's a norm to receive howlers or stinker emails in capslock on days off and public holidays. It takes a really long time to recover from such a place even after you switch to something better.

pros: Content management, which is our department, is good. They try their hardest to work under pressure and under bad HR & higher management
cons:
Under-appreciated. The higher-ups above our department could care less about our worth as an employee. They only see our wrongdoings, only pay attention when the results don't meet their goals, and demand us to do more without any returns, not even a simple acknowledgement! Only when you want to leave the company (and if you're a star player) that they'll notice you and say that you're "highly" valuable to the point of trying really hard to persuade you not to leave.
On top of that, the HR does not tender to the employees properly and really late at everything. Some of our confirmation letters were received one to two months late, even after our team leaders pushed them. And instead of listening to the employee's needs and concerns, they just implement some random things that would distract from their lack of real responsibilities.

pros: I don't see much, just the infrastructure. But for that too, too chilled (AC's).
cons: No work/life balance, poor management, arrogant seniors. They hire you for 9hrs a day with Sunday off but once you start working with them, you are required to work late daily (3-4hr is normal), you are required to work 7 days a week and working extra is applicable for 7 days, even for lunch breaks you gotta wait till 4pm or so. They expect you to report at 9am or 10am and work till 12am (for girls)/ 3am (for boys) and report on time next day. A company can sustain in market only if they think of their employees too, rather than just juicing them out. I can vouch even if an employee is dying there, they wont allow lunch breaks (even if its way past lunch time already), they will still ask you for over time and expect you to report the next day (even if its your off/sunday).

pros:
•	Plan marketing and branding objectives.
•	Prepare marketing strategies alongside other company executives and staff.
•	Oversee creation and delivery of press releases, advertisements and other marketing materials.
•	Design print ads and publications.
•	Ensure brand messages are consistent.
•	Gather and analyze customer insight.
•	Nurture and enrich all external perceptions of the company and growth of market share.
•	Deepen relationships with all media to ensure the most effective messaging and positioning of the organization.
•	Lead all areas of content generation and production across all media platforms.
•	Take calculated risks based on data-driven analytics and deliver marketing activity within agreed budget.
•	Collaborate with sales to develop strategic partnership activities and implement the execution framework and strategic plan on identified opportunities.
•	Manage brand ambassadors team and engage in on ground events.
•	Responsible for all PR activations.
•	Brainstorm new and creative growth strategies.
•	Collaborate with the central teams to increase engagement and optimize user experience.
•	Collaborate with agencies, suppliers and other vendor partners.
cons:
Time management
Needs to know how to recommend changes to marketing and business development strategies based on analysis and feedback.

review_title: A good place to start your entrepreneurial journey
pros:
- More responsibilities with less or  no supervision
- Ideal for young entrepreneurial talents who wants to take actions and build something big
- You work with the best talents and senior managers (in case they work in the same office)
cons:
- Lack of communication at early stages
- Co founders and CEO's in the GCC are not visible all the time, I met my managers twice a year
- They always follow what global management KPIs requires no matter what the local market requires or local consumers need.
- Sometimes they lose sight of what should be done, because of the lack of communication and understanding of the local market.

review_title: Never take up an offer from foodpanda. If you do, roll over and die. God help you!
pros:
None. Consider yourself lucky if you receive your monthly salary on time.
Forget perks and incentives. 
No structure, no process, top management guys party all days, company runs mainly because of the overt funding and nothing else. 
Inexperienced overcompensated top management.
No hierarchy, no process.
cons:
Terrible work culture. 
False commitments.
One day you wake up in the morning only to get a call saying you are fired.
Frequent change in top management. Place is literally a mess. No coordination. You look over both your shoulders before you get out of your house, meaning you might have gotten yourself fired for no reason whatsoever.
Your boss might turn out to be the most underqualified person, ever.
Never work here. You will get better opportunities.

review_title: Not a place to really consider.
pros:
Seems quite open to the use of lots of tools and compete hard.
There is some talented people there, to bad their wasted into endless hours and bad management.
cons:
Crappy management. I got out of here very demotivated. May things have change now that is under delivery heroe. Though hopefully anyone doesnt have to go through what i went.  Firing people with no reasons or explanations whatsoever- You got fire and out in a manner of an hour, told you to pick up whatever was yours on the desk and dont bother to say by to your colleages-
Insulting peoples job by being dishonest basically. When demotivation hit few departments no management or HR did nothing to prevent it or motivate people.  Overall Some people are not open to progress, are not willing to change or adapt or neither have some bit of humanity to emphasize. Lots of fear run that place for a long while.

review_title: Experience of working in a start-up
pros: You're building something from the ground up for the company to succeed. A cool, open-minded work environment with large amount of responsibility and decision-making capacity from day one. Opportunities to grow quickly and move up in your career.Greater transparency than in many larger companies.
cons: When you join a start-up, don't expect a clarity of your Job Description. Heavy workloads, tight deadlines with no week-offs. If you're ready to give it your all, a startup may bring out the best in you. However, if you have other major commitments or like being able to clock off at five o'clock on the dot, this culture may not be for you.

review_title: Great company with a lot of potential
pros:
- management team that really believes in their vision for foodpanda
- international team with many motivated and great individuals
- globally operating company with many exciting projects to work on
- transparency regarding the situation and development of the company
cons:
- sometimes it is hard to feel connected to the brand as the HQ is in Berlin and the operations are on the ground in emerging markets
- very dynamic environment which means that priorities are sometimes changing very quickly and the communication regarding that is not always ideal
- not all managers are equally experienced and thus some departments lack a bit of leadership

review_title: Good Salary, not so Good Management
pros: Very good compensation. non-taxable allowances: Gives you atleast 3k for Gas allowance, 1500 rice allowance, 1500 meal allowance 3k food reimbursable when you order thru foodpanda every month. Get to meet Restaurants' owner and gets free food in very meeting. Provided with company phone that comes with LTE sim, unlimited data and calls/text to all network. With medical insurance.
cons: Expat CEO, doesnt take in suggestions and always imposing what they want.

review_title: Good as a first job experience, bad otherwise
pros: Flat hierarchy and an "execution mindset" within the team makes it possible to influence and create a lot on your own.
cons: All problems of early stage start-ups are still all too present: lack of structure, processes are not followed or non existent, strategic directions changes very often, high employee turnover, etc. Most problematic though is a inexcusable lack of care for people regarding internal communications, personal development, career plans and transparency within the organization

pros: - you learn a lot
cons:
- bad management
- no benefits for employees
- nothing is done to make employees happy
- no career progress appart for the employees of the HQ in Berlin
- too many changes
- average time of an employee in the company : 6 month
- Firing like crazy
- need to fight to get what you want

job_title: Business Development Manager in Hong Kong
pros:
Joining foodpanda was a really good decision at the beginning. 

You go through the Skype interviews, you get into the country and in the first day you handle a lot of responsibilities that you have no idea how to manage. But that is a good thing right? You are ambitious so you give the best from yourself and you start learning, really fast and a huge range of different things, of different departments, how to lead people, how to build teams... You experienced a real start-up there!
cons:
The company is too big now to give you that "start-up" feeling. It is difficult to get involved in other departments and learn fast and from every department. 

They treat people like nothing. Honestly.

review_title: Challenging and fun place to work
pros: Dynamic, fast-changing, embracing change, challenging, very high level of responsibilities, great opportunities for corporate and personal development, team work , team events, smart and extremely international colleagues, company that challenges oneself to stand up, criticizes and be heard in order to improve processes and drive culture and success of the company
cons: communication to be improved, even more cross-departmental communication and exchange of best-practices needed!!

review_title: Worst ever company to work with!!!
pros: Absolutely NO Pros about this company!!
cons:
Unethical, Unprofessional, Totally Inconsistent, Mismanagement, Corrupted Top Level Management.
I had worked for Foodpanda India, put all my efforts, over achieved my targets in half of the time frame, and I even had been doing things that were not coming under my responsibility, just because I loved working and I was over sincere to my work. But in the two months course of my overall experience, I could feel unprofessionalism everywhere.
The policies of the company keep changing every now and then. They are so inconsistent with their terms and policies, they badly keep following Zomato for everything and keep blaming Zomato as well, still copies all their strategies. They claim, everything is being decided from Berlin!! God knows if they really have a team in Berlin lol! HR never responds! It took me 45 days trying to communicate with HR requesting my employee code. I have sent nearly 10 emails to HR in my two months requesting for Employee code and appointment letter.  Kept trying for the appointment letter, but till date, I never received such a document! The tragedy comes all of a sudden! One fine day, being at work, in the field, I could not access my official mail. I had two of my colleagues working in the same city, none of us could either access out mail or salesforce login. It was then, that we released that we are terminated! That too with no reason, no explanation, no prior notice. We had pretty good track record, performed really well, but still this is what the company rewarded us with! The reason they said was that, the Berlin team deiced to pull out their business from Tier II cities and so they are shutting down operations in my city. But in reality, Foodpanda is doing business in full swing with the restaurant partners whom me and my team signed up with. They just avoided us after utilizing us. 
Message to anyone who is planning to join Foodpanda : Please do not risk your career, future in Foodpanda, the company sucks! I had the same review from another victim who worked with Foodpanda in my same city, two years back as well.

review_title: Very bad management, salary issues, focusing on rules
pros:
-  Good team leads & good teammates.
- Understanding team lead & some of them are flexible 
- Flexibility on your schedule
- Following the Labour law by giving EPF & SOCSO
- Medical card & monthly food/drinks allowance only will be given after a year
- Very fast response from HR when comes to salary shortage (not sure about others)
cons:
- Very bad management
- No transparency ( Was given a different position for what have applied for) there is no courtesy to inform you that they have appointed you to a different department. There are also other agents who experience the same thing. AND

- HR lack of knowledge- Asked one of the HR in regards to the other opening for the part-time position, however, we were told only that particular position is available, so I applied for that.  During the induction, the HR mentioned that the part-time position that I applied has already closed. 


- 15 minutes break for part-timers (you can't be late, if not disciplinary action will be taken )- How could you order and eat for 15 minutes? if you are hungry? as a part-timer, we need to have our tummy heal as well. AND 

- Everything in the office " toilet (15 min) &   break " is a must to inform via verbal and in chat groups. Well, I do understand certain call centers do adhere such rule esp punctuality, but the 15 mins toilet break & 15 min break ( part-timers) is unacceptable plus have to inform in the group.

- Too focus on rules- If you are late, you have to inform the group and yes, it makes sense. What does not makes sense is when you make in an accident,  one of the TL replied that whether have you inform the reporting TL (about the absence)? and the TL is in the group. Come on,  in this situation you still ask this rather than your subordinate's well-being? 

- Every month shortage-  At the first month of the employment, there is no salary was paid, when asked about the reason from the HR,  there was no clear answer given only have to liaise with the TL or fill in the form which later did fill accordingly and the person who handles the pay comes back and the pay was credited into the account the next day. Even many employees experience shortage every month. (and note that its just a part-time salary and it's much lower than the full-time earnings)

- Hiring more employees? - If you are really hiring more people, kindly provide enough space for them. We have to wait even at the point of 2 hours just to get a seat and do our job, and remember, we still have to accomplish the KPI despite the waiting.  If the management has already done the plan to get more space, then  is awesome, if not pls take action asap.
